one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle‑aged woman with advanced HIV/AIDS off HAART, ESRD on thrice‑weekly hemodialysis, chronic anemia, and chronic pain presented with pleuritic substernal chest pain and new odynophagia. Initial evaluation showed stable vital signs, a normal EKG, and chest imaging without acute cardiopulmonary pathology; CTA chest ruled out pulmonary embolism and aortic dissection, and serial cardiac enzymes showed modest troponin elevation with flat CK‑MB, interpreted as non‑ischemic in the setting of ESRD. She subsequently developed high fevers and was found to have coagulase‑negative staphylococcal bacteremia, attributed to her tunneled hemodialysis catheter; broad‑spectrum antibiotics were started, then narrowed to vancomycin, and the infected line was removed after multidisciplinary discussion. Because venography demonstrated bilateral central subclavian occlusions, a tunneled right femoral hemodialysis catheter was placed for ongoing access. GI evaluation for chest discomfort and dysphagia included an upper GI barium study, which was normal, and EGD, which showed gastritis and duodenitis; she was started on omeprazole with symptomatic improvement. She also developed a small left lower lobe pneumonia on chest radiograph, treated transiently with cefepime until radiographic resolution and persistently negative cultures. Throughout the stay she continued sevelamer, cinacalcet, epoetin, vitamin D analogs, and renal vitamins for ESRD and secondary hyperparathyroidism, and Bactrim and azithromycin prophylaxis were restarted for HIV. By discharge she was afebrile, hemodynamically stable, ambulating independently, tolerating diet with improved odynophagia, and had negative follow‑up blood cultures; she was discharged home with services, to continue vancomycin with dialysis and her revised outpatient medication regimen.

problem_list.problem: Pleuritic chest pain, non‑ischemic and likely gastrointestinal/musculoskeletal in origin
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Initial pleuritic substernal chest pain prompted full cardiac and pulmonary evaluation; CTA chest showed no pulmonary embolism or aortic pathology, chest X‑ray was clear, and serial enzymes showed modest troponin elevation with flat CK‑MB in the setting of ESRD. EKG remained normal. Pain resolved with Percocet and antacid/viscous lidocaine therapy, and GI workup revealed only mild gastritis/duodenitis. She had no recurrent chest pain by discharge.

problem_list.problem: Coagulase‑negative staphylococcal bacteremia due to hemodialysis catheter
problem_list.status_at_discharge: On hospital day 2 she developed high fevers and blood cultures grew coagulase‑negative Staphylococcus, with the tunneled hemodialysis catheter considered the source. She was treated with IV vancomycin (cefepime stopped after 3 days once no gram‑negative source was identified), and the infected line was removed after persistent fevers. Subsequent surveillance blood cultures were negative, and she was discharged to continue vancomycin with dialysis for a planned extended course.

Later in the admission she had a recurrent fever and chest radiograph showed a new small left lower lobe pneumonia without effusion. She was started on cefepime; cultures remained negative and a follow‑up chest X‑ray showed decreased infiltrate with only streaky atelectasis. Cefepime was discontinued prior to discharge, and she was clinically improved without respiratory symptoms.

problem_list.problem: End‑stage renal disease on hemodialysis with complex vascular access
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She remained dialysis‑dependent on a Monday‑Wednesday‑Friday schedule. During evaluation for catheter‑related infection, venography showed occlusion of both central subclavian veins, precluding new upper‑body access. After a line holiday, a tunneled right femoral hemodialysis catheter was placed with its tip in the right atrium and deemed ready for use. She continued sevelamer, cinacalcet, vitamin D analogs, epoetin, and Nephrocaps, and was discharged to continue outpatient hemodialysis via the femoral catheter.

She presented with new odynophagia and poor appetite. Upper GI barium study showed no esophageal ulcer or stricture, and EGD demonstrated erythema, congestion, and petechiae in the gastric body and antrum consistent with gastritis, and erythema in the duodenal bulb consistent with duodenitis. She was started on omeprazole 20 mg twice daily with improvement in swallowing discomfort and was discharged on this regimen, with the caveat that omeprazole may need to be changed when HAART is restarted.

problem_list.problem: Advanced HIV/AIDS off HAART with prophylaxis restarted
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has longstanding HIV/AIDS with a recent CD4 count of 59 and prior PCP episodes, and had been off HAART due to non‑adherence. During this admission, ID recommended restarting Pneumocystis and MAC prophylaxis; she was discharged on sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim three times weekly and azithromycin twice weekly. Full antiretroviral therapy was deferred to outpatient ID follow‑up, with attention to potential interactions with omeprazole.

problem_list.problem: Chronic anemia and leukopenia in chronic kidney disease
problem_list.status_at_discharge: CBCs throughout the stay showed macrocytic anemia with hemoglobin generally 8–10 g/dL and hematocrit in the high 20s to low 30s, with mild leukopenia and normal platelets, consistent with her baseline anemia of CKD and chronic cytopenias. She received epoetin with dialysis and was restarted on folic acid and Nephrocaps. No transfusions were required, and there was no evidence of acute bleeding.

problem_list.problem: Chronic pain syndrome / myalgias and arthralgias
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has longstanding diffuse myalgias and arthralgias with prior neurologic evaluation. During admission she required Percocet for pain control, which also relieved her initial chest discomfort. No new focal neurologic deficits were noted, and she was discharged on oxycodone‑acetaminophen with instructions regarding maximum daily acetaminophen dose and outpatient neurology follow‑up.

key_tests_and_results.test: Initial chest imaging and CT angiography
key_tests_and_results.result: Chest X‑ray on admission showed no acute cardiopulmonary process and a stable left‑sided dialysis catheter. CTA chest demonstrated no pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome, only mild bibasilar atelectasis and renal cysts.
Troponin T was modestly elevated (0.15–0.26 ng/mL) with flat CK‑MB values and no ischemic changes on EKG, interpreted as non‑ischemic elevation in the setting of ESRD.
Esophagram showed no mass, stricture, mucosal irregularity, reflux, or hiatal hernia; barium passed freely into the stomach with normal peristalsis, arguing against structural esophageal disease.

EGD revealed erythema, congestion, and petechiae in the gastric body and antrum compatible with gastritis, and erythema and congestion in the duodenal bulb compatible with duodenitis; the esophagus and distal duodenum were otherwise normal.

Initial blood cultures grew coagulase‑negative Staphylococcus, consistent with catheter‑related bloodstream infection. Subsequent surveillance blood cultures after line removal were negative or showed no growth to date, indicating clearance of bacteremia.

Interventional venography demonstrated complete thrombosis of the central left subclavian vein and non‑visualization of the right subclavian/SVC, precluding new IJ access. A tunneled right common femoral hemodialysis catheter was subsequently placed with its tip in the right atrium without complication.
Follow‑up chest X‑ray showed a new small left lower lobe pneumonia without effusion, which decreased on repeat imaging with only streaky residual changes after cefepime therapy.

Ultrasound of the left upper extremity veins showed normal flow, compressibility, and augmentation in the subclavian, internal jugular, axillary, brachial, basilic, and cephalic veins, with no evidence of DVT.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Broad‑spectrum and targeted IV antibiotics for catheter‑related bloodstream infection
treatments_and_meds.details: After onset of high fevers and positive blood cultures for coagulase‑negative staphylococci, she was started on IV vancomycin and cefepime. Once cultures confirmed coagulase‑negative staph without gram‑negative organisms, cefepime was discontinued and vancomycin was continued, including dosing per hemodialysis protocol. Following line removal and negative surveillance cultures, she was discharged to complete an extended course of vancomycin administered with outpatient dialysis.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Removal of infected hemodialysis catheter and placement of tunneled femoral catheter
treatments_and_meds.details: Because of persistent fevers and coagulase‑negative staph bacteremia, her existing tunneled hemodialysis catheter was removed after multidisciplinary discussion. Venography during attempted IJ catheter placement revealed occlusion of both central subclavian veins. The following day, a tunneled right common femoral hemodialysis catheter was placed under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance, with the tip positioned in the right atrium and deemed ready for use.

She continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis during the admission, with adjustments around line removal and replacement. She received epoetin alfa, doxercalciferol, and heparin during dialysis sessions, and remained on sevelamer carbonate, cinacalcet, and Nephrocaps. Laboratory trends showed persistently elevated creatinine and BUN consistent with ESRD, with values improving after dialysis sessions.

For odynophagia and chest discomfort suspected to be gastrointestinal, she was treated with antacid/viscous lidocaine mixtures and then transitioned to omeprazole 20 mg twice daily after EGD confirmed gastritis and duodenitis. Symptoms of burning and swallowing discomfort improved on this regimen, with instructions to adjust acid suppression if HAART is restarted.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: HIV prophylaxis and planning for HAART
treatments_and_meds.details: Given her low CD4 count and history of PCP, she was restarted on sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim prophylaxis three times weekly and azithromycin twice weekly for MAC prophylaxis. Full antiretroviral therapy was not restarted in‑hospital due to prior non‑adherence and potential interactions with omeprazole; this was deferred to her outpatient ID specialist with social work support.

When a new left lower lobe pneumonia was identified on chest radiograph in the setting of fever, she was treated with cefepime. With negative cultures and radiographic improvement on follow‑up imaging, cefepime was discontinued prior to discharge.

Her chronic diffuse myalgias and arthralgias, as well as initial chest discomfort, were managed with oxycodone‑acetaminophen (Percocet) as needed. She was discharged with Percocet and additional acetaminophen instructions, with outpatient neurology follow‑up planned.

disposition.discharge_location: Home with home health services and outpatient hemodialysis
